Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Microfluidically Loaded Highly Reconfigurable Compact RF Devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CAREER: Microfluidically Loaded Highly Reconfigurable Compact RF Devices

Intellectual Merits:
This CAREER effort investigates the interdisciplinary concept of microfluidically loaded reconfigurability within the context of RF antennas, filters, and imaging systems. These devices operate based on a new technique that relies on continuously movable microfluidic loads consisting of metal (liquid/solid) and dielectric solution volumes. Different than the recent work that relied on fluidic tubes and one-time reconfigurability, the proposed integrated microfluidic channel realizations with thin insulator walls truly allows for maximizing the parasitic loading based reconfigurability offered by the liquid volumes. The proposed effort investigates both flexible soft substrate device realizations and rigid hard substrate implementations to provide superior reconfigurability performances in terms of frequency tunability, agility, power handling, size, and speed. The project also envisions a novel microfluidic based reconfigurability approach based on employing metalized quartz pieces within the microfluidic channels. This constitutes a major deviation from existing approach of utilizing liquid metals and paves the way for low-cost non-toxic highly reconfigurable microfluidically loaded RF components. Systematic studies are planned to characterize and improve the reliability of the proposed devices under certain mechanical impact and stress conditions in order to advance the state of microfluidically reconfigured devices from simplistic conceptual laboratory prototype demonstrations to the system level integrations.
Broader Impacts:
There is currently a strong need for low cost, easy to use, mm and sub-mm wave imaging/radar technologies. Next generation satellite, ground-to-air, air-to-air communications and radar technologies will demand easy-to-use low-cost highly reconfigurable and self-adapting RF front-ends. The power handling capability of reconfigurable compact filters have historically been an important challenge, and the proposed effort holds promise to alleviate these concerns. The proposed reconfigurable devices and imaging systems, if successful, hold potential to transform such technologies from complicated military platforms, luxury cars, expensive devices, and specialized hospitals into general use to benefit the society. The educational plan is centered on providing learning opportunities by leveraging unique partnerships with Florida Advance Technological Education Center (FL-ATE) and NSF Florida-George Louis Strokes Alliance for Minority Participation (FGLSAMP). An important contribution will be the initiation of a 3D visualization centric electromagnetic theory education by utilizing USF's recently established Advanced Visualization Center (AVC). The 3D visualizations and interdisciplinary nature of the project will be used to support outreach activities with elementary and high schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This CAREER award investigated the concept of microfluidically loaded reconfigurability within the context of RF antennas, filters, and imaging systems. New fabrication techniques were introduced to (i) integrate microfluidic channels in close proximity of the RF device metallizations, (ii) utilize hard substrates in device construction, and (iii) realize liquid-metal-free devices by replacing liquid metal volumes with microfluidically repositionable selectively metallized plates. By utilizing these fabrication techniques and pursuing novel design approaches, a variety of highly reconfigurable RF devices were successfully demonstrated in terms of functionality and power handling capabilities. Earlier work showed antennas and antenna arrays operating at or below 5 GHz frequencies that can radiate efficiently and provide frequency tunability over a significantly large bandwidth (>2:1). This was followed with the successful demonstrations of RF bandpass filters exhibiting large frequency tunability (>2:1) while maintaining low insertion loss. High radiation efficiencies and low insertion losses of the microfluidically reconfigurable antennas and RF bandpass filters were shown to be suitable for high power handling with device characterizations demonstrating >10W continuous RF power handling. These type of frequency tunable antennas and RF bandpass filters is expected to benefit frequency agile wireless communication systems that are likely to be at the backbone of the future generation mobile communications. The concepts utilized in RF bandpass filter design were also expanded to realize a near field surface imaging system. The system operated at 10 GHz with subwavelength imaging capability and it can be expanded as a low-cost and low-complexity microwave imager for material and structural health characterizations.

 

The research work carried out under this CAREER award also considered mm-wave applications of the microfluidically reconfigurable RF devices. Future generation mobile communication systems plan to utilize mm-wave bands (e.g. 28 GHz) to enhance data rates. However, significant technological advances are needed to overcome the unique challenges of mm-wave communications. The path loss in mm-wave frequencies necessitate to employ antenna arrays with beam-steering functionality. Such antenna arrays are currently costly and complex to construct. This project introduced microfluidic focal plane antenna arrays (MFPAs) as an alternative approach for low cost implementation of high gain beam-steering mm-wave antenna arrays. The key components within the developed 28 GHz MFPA is microfluidically reconfigurable mm-wave switches. In a further study, it was demonstrated that these mm-wave switches can be significantly miniaturized through design and material modifications. This paves the way to realize compact beam-steering antenna arrays in mm-wave frequencies by using microfluidics. Most importantly, it was demonstrated that these switches can be integrated with piezoelectric actuators and be operated with actuation times down to 1.2 ms (and potentially lower with future improvements). Integrated actuation of microfluidic RF devices is a key advancement towards their practical use since external bulky components (i.e. pumps) can be now completely avoided. Final device work in the project was carried out for the design and demonstration of a novel mm-wave agile bandpass filter simultaneously exhibiting bandwidth and frequency tuning capabilities.  Specifically, frequency tunability from 28 GHz to 38 GHz and fractional bandwidth tunability from 7% to 12% at 28 GHz and 6.8% to 16.9% at 38 GHz was demonstrated with a compact device using the integrated actuation mechanism.

 

Educational plan of the award focused on implementation and incorporation of a 3D visualization centric electromagnetic education concept within the undergraduate level electromagnetics course.  For this purpose, 3D visualizations were developed and presented to students in the Advanced Visualization Center (AVC) of University of South Florida. These visualizations allow the instructor of the course to change the perspective on demand and demonstrate how the mathematical/geometrical operations and abstract concepts (such as electromagnetic fields, radiation, electron beams, etc) relate to the physical phenomena. Different visualization types are presented that include coordinate systems, vector algebra and calculus, electrostatics, and time varying EM fields.
